title: Halloween decorations: 5 festive DIY cake topper ideas
text:
CLOSE

Cake decorated with a plethora of DIY Halloween toppers. (Photo: Kelly Bryden, MakeItGrateful.com)

To celebrate Halloween, we’ve created five different cake toppers you can make with supplies around your house.

Five seems like a lot, but don’t worry – you don’t need to (but could) put them all on one cake. We’ll walk you through steps on how to make an easy cake topper in under five minutes as well as more complicated cake toppers that will take a little more effort. What we love about all five is that they are made with pieces you can most likely find around your home. So no excuses for a boring cake! Let’s get to making them.

GOOGLY-EYED FOREST CAKE TOPPERS — EASY

Materials

Wooden sticks

Googly eyes

Hot glue

Eyeballs glued on wood sticks. (Photo: Kelly Bryden, MakeItGrateful.com)

This is a one-step wonder. Simply glue googly eyes onto wooden sticks and you are done. What makes this cake topper interesting is varying the type and amount of googly eyes you glue onto each stick. Glue some horizontal, vertical, eight on a stick, one on a stick – go crazy with it!

DIY eyeball cake toppers in cake. (Photo: Kelly Bryden, MakeItGrateful.com)

You will then want to put them into your cake at different heights. Make the googly eyes appear from all different angles. Just as if creepy crawly creatures were lurking in bushes and all you could see was the glow of their eyes.

GHOST CAKE TOPPERS — RELATIVELY EASY

Materials

Cotton balls

Tissues

Black paper

Wooden sticks

Scissors

Hot glue gun

Art supplies and tools for making DIY cake toppers. (Photo: Kelly Bryden, MakeItGrateful.com)

This isn’t as easy as the first one, but this Halloween cake topper still only has three steps.

Step 1

Glue the cotton ball onto the top of the wooden stick.

Glue gun with wood sticks and cotton balls. (Photo: Kelly Bryden, MakeItGrateful.com)

Step 2

Cover the top of the cotton ball with hot glue and stick it in the center of the tissue. Use your hands to press the tissue down so it drapes over the cotton ball. You might need to add a few extra drops of glue on the inside to hold the tissue in place and create a nice ghostly draping effect.

Tissues glued to wooden sticks. (Photo: Kelly Bryden, MakeItGrateful.com)

Step 3

Cut out small circles of black paper for the eyes and mouth, and glue them onto the face of the ghost.

DIY ghost cake toppers. (Photo: Kelly Bryden, MakeItGrateful.com)

Ghosts are always more fun in a group, so make a couple to top off your Halloween cake.

WITCH LEG CAKE TOPPERS — MEDIUM

Materials

Toilet paper tubes

Orange paper

Yellow paper

White paper

Black paper

Scissors

Glue

Construction paper, art scissors and empty toilet paper rolls. (Photo: Kelly Bryden, MakeItGrateful.com)

Who doesn’t love a good toilet paper tube hack?

Step 1

Cut out strips of orange, yellow and white paper, and glue them onto the toilet paper tube. I used colored contact paper, which made it a breeze but isn’t necessary to buy if you don’t have it around. You could also use colored duct tape or washi tape.

These tubes will be the witch’s legs – a witch wearing striped stockings.

Paper wrapped around empty toilet rolls. (Photo: Kelly Bryden, MakeItGrateful.com)

Step 2

Draw and cut out two witch’s shoes from black paper. I used a Google image as a reference to look at a witch shoe while I was drawing.

Step 3

Cut two 3/4-inch slits at the top of the toilet paper tube and slide the cut-out shoe to sit at the top.

DIY witch shoes with paper and empty toilet rolls. (Photo: Kelly Bryden, MakeItGrateful.com)

Step 4

Place the witch’s legs sticking out of the top of the cake and you have an adorable Halloween cake topper.

Halloween DIY craft witch shoes cake topper in a cake. (Photo: Kelly Bryden, MakeItGrateful.com)

PUMPKIN PATCH CAKE TOPPERS — MEDIUM/DIFFICULT

Materials

Orange yarn

Black paper

Wooden sticks

Pompom maker

Hot glue gun

Art supplies for DIY cake toppers. (Photo: Kelly Bryden, MakeItGrateful.com)

Step 1

Wrap yarn around both sides of your pompom maker until the sides look full.

Orange warm and art scissors. (Photo: Kelly Bryden, MakeItGrateful.com)

Step 2

Cut down the center of each side and then wrap an extra piece of string through the middle. Tie tightly and then release from the pompom maker.

Craft scissors with orange pom pom. (Photo: Kelly Bryden, MakeItGrateful.com)

Step 3

Trim up the pompom to look like a pumpkin. The more you trim off, the more dense your pompom will look.

Step 4

Glue your pompoms onto the top of a wooden stick, or you can glue a piece of cardstock to the bottom of the pompom if you want it to sit directly on the cake. No one wants to mix yarn and frosting.

Orange pompoms glued onto wooden sticks. (Photo: Kelly Bryden, MakeItGrateful.com)

Step 5

Cut out small shapes from black cardstock and glue them onto the pompoms to create Jack-o’-lantern faces.

Pumpkin pompom balls with art supplies. (Photo: Kelly Bryden, MakeItGrateful.com)

Not your typical Charlie Brown pumpkin patch. Take this cake topper to the next level by adding candy corn and candy corn pumpkins around the edges.

Pompom pumpkins used as DIY Halloween cake toppers. (Photo: Kelly Bryden, MakeItGrateful.com)

More: How to make a DIY rainbow Halloween costume

SPIDERWEB CAKE TOPPERS — DIFFICULT

Materials

Spiderweb print-out

Eek print-out

Wax paper

Hot glue

Paint

Hot glue gun

Striped straws

Art supplies for making DIY Halloween cake toppers. (Photo: Kelly Bryden, MakeItGrateful.com)

Step 1

Print out an image of a spiderweb and cover it with a piece of wax paper. Trace over the spider web with your glue gun, leaving behind a spider web made out of hot glue. You will want to make sure your web has thick lines and good connections, because you won’t want it to break when assembling the cake topper.

Hot glue over spider web stencil. (Photo: Kelly Bryden, MakeItGrateful.com)

Step 2

Follow the same steps with your lettering. You can choose any word or phrase, but make sure your stencil is in script lettering. You will want all the letters to connect to make it easier to attach to the web.

Hot glue on stencil with glue gun. (Photo: Kelly Bryden, MakeItGrateful.com)

Step 3

Once the glue has dried (which should be pretty instant), peel it off the wax paper and remove all the extra hot glue strings. You can also use an X-Acto knife to trim up the edges if your hot gluing got out of hand.

Step 4

Paint over your hot glue pieces with acrylic paint. You will probably need two coats of paint to get a good covering.

Painted hot-glue spiderweb. (Photo: Kelly Bryden, MakeItGrateful.com)

More: Halloween makeup trends that will be popular in 2019

Step 5

Time to assemble your cake topper. Glue the spiderweb to two straws and then place the lettering on top of the spiderweb. Stick it on top of your cake and no one will ever know this was made from hot glue!

DIY spider web Halloween cake topper made with hot glue. (Photo: Kelly Bryden, MakeItGrateful.com)

And if you are making all five, then you might as well put them all together into one crazy cake topper.
